Table 1: 
Unbiased DME algorithms’ guarantees (without variable-length encoding; see Appendix A) using b=O​(1)𝑏𝑂1b=O(1) bits per coordinate and using the Hadamard transform for rotation-based algorithms.
references:
QUIC-FL is also significantly more accurate than all other approaches. We observe that the default TF configuration of Kashin’s representation suffers from a bias, and therefore its 𝑁𝑀𝑆𝐸𝑁𝑀𝑆𝐸\mathit{NMSE} is not O​(1/n)𝑂1𝑛O(1/n). In contrast, the theoretical algorithm is unbiased but has an asymptotically slower encoding time. We observed similar trends for different n,b𝑛𝑏n,b, and d𝑑d values. We consider the algorithms’ bandwidth over all coordinates (i.e., with b+64512𝑏64512b+\frac{64}{512} bits for QUIC-FL, namely a float and a 32-bit index for each accurately sent entry).
Overall, the empirical measurements fall in line with the bounds in Table 1.

The approach we take corresponds to the following process. We move probability mass from the leftmost, then uppermost entry with non-zero mass to its right neighbor in the server table. So, for example, in Table 2, as V¯c​[i]subscript¯𝑉𝑐delimited-[]𝑖\overline{V}_{c}[i] increases from 0, we first move mass from the entry H¯c​[i]=2,X¯c​[i]=1formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝐻𝑐delimited-[]𝑖2subscript¯𝑋𝑐delimited-[]𝑖1\overline{H}_{c}[i]=2,\overline{X}_{c}[i]=1 to the entry H¯c​[i]=2,X¯c​[i]=2formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝐻𝑐delimited-[]𝑖2subscript¯𝑋𝑐delimited-[]𝑖2\overline{H}_{c}[i]=2,\overline{X}_{c}[i]=2. That is, the client, based on its private randomness, increases the probability of message X¯c​[i]=2subscript¯𝑋𝑐delimited-[]𝑖2\overline{X}_{c}[i]=2 and decreases the probability of message X¯c​[i]=1subscript¯𝑋𝑐delimited-[]𝑖1\overline{X}_{c}[i]=1 when H¯c​[i]=2subscript¯𝐻𝑐delimited-[]𝑖2\overline{H}_{c}[i]=2. The amount of mass moved is always chosen to maintain unbiasedness.
At some point, as V¯c​[i]subscript¯𝑉𝑐delimited-[]𝑖\overline{V}_{c}[i] increases, all of the probability mass will have moved, and then we start moving mass from H¯c​[i]=3,X¯c​[i]=1formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝐻𝑐delimited-[]𝑖3subscript¯𝑋𝑐delimited-[]𝑖1\overline{H}_{c}[i]=3,\overline{X}_{c}[i]=1 similarly. (And subsequently, from H¯c​[i]=0,X¯c​[i]=2formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝐻𝑐delimited-[]𝑖0subscript¯𝑋𝑐delimited-[]𝑖2\overline{H}_{c}[i]=0,\overline{X}_{c}[i]=2 and so on.)

references: The Shakespeare next-word prediction discussed in §4 was first suggested in McMahan et al. (2017) to naturally simulate a realistic heterogeneous federated learning setting. Its dataset consists of 18,424 lines of text from Shakespeare plays Shakespeare  partitioned among the respective 715 speakers (i.e., clients). We train a standard LSTM recurrent model Hochreiter & Schmidhuber (1997) with ≈820​Kabsent820𝐾{\approx}820K parameters and follow precisely the setup described in Reddi et al. (2021) for the Adam server optimizer case. We restate the hyperparameters for convenience in Table 4.
